page.title: 03Landscape Of Notgrove
page.content: The landscape of this block is of a gently undulating patchwork of large cultivated fields, interspersed with sheep and cattle. In a fold of this terrain fresh water was found and people settled giving rise to the village of Notgrove. The cottages all built in locally quarried yellow stone and brown tiled roofs blend into this rural landscape. Todays policy is to perpetuate this characteristic, so no red brick or blue tiles are allowed. The cottages, some terraced others detached, all have an individual identity, although as most are owned by the Notgrove Estate a light green paint is uniformly used throughout the village. One notable archetechtoral feature is the impressive Notgrove Manor, 17th century in origin, with a wing added this century, all of course in the Cotswold style and stone.
